GRANT AND PROGRAM SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) 
   
The Proposal  The proposal comprises (i) a program cluster for the Private Sector and 
Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises Development Program (PSME) 
Cluster, comprising two subprograms (subprogram 1 and 2) covering 
reforms  in  institutional  development  in  SME  policy  formulation  and 
implementation, access to finance, investment climate, trade policy and 
capacity  building,  and  macroeconomic  stability;  and  (ii)  a  proposed 
grant of $5 million for subprogram 1 of the cluster, and a proposal to 
administer a technical assistance grant from the Japan Special Fund 
(JSF).  
   
Classification  Targeting Classification: General intervention 
Sector: Law, economic management, and public policy 
Subsector: Economic management 
Themes: Private sector development, governance, sustainable 
economic growth 
Subthemes: Promoting institutional/regulatory reforms, economic 
governance, and macroeconomic stability

Assessment 
   
The Program  The  core  objective  of  the  Government’s  Sixth  Socio-Economic 
Rationale  Development Plan (SEDP6) is sustaining economic growth of 7%–8% 
per year, while reducing poverty. SEDP6 targets poverty incidence of 
23% by 2015, and the creation of 652,000 jobs during 2006 and 2010. 
Private sector expansion is considered a key mechanism for achieving 
these two objectives. Poverty rates have declined in Lao PDR from 
46% in 1992 to 33% in 2003, a remarkable achievement given the rapid 
population growth during this period. As much as half the population is 
now  under  20  years  old.  Poverty  reduction  has  been  driven  by 
economic  expansion,  opening  up  of  the  economy  to  trade  and 
investment, increased rice production, greater urbanization, and higher 
remittances from Lao workers abroad. A sharp reduction in poverty is 
common once a country passes a certain per capita income threshold, 
as Lao PDR has done. Further poverty reduction of the magnitude 
SEDP6 is targeting will depend on sustaining economic growth at the 
current rate of 7% per year over the medium term, as well as mobilizing 
additional fiscal resources to support long-term development and social 
spending objectives. Lao PDR has the potential to accomplish these 
goals,  and  the  private  sector  increasingly  will  be  relied  upon  to 
accomplish them.  
The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  country  strategy  and  program 
(CSP) for 2007–2011 prioritizes private sector development (PSD). As 
one  PSD  outcome  indicator,  the  CSP  has  targeted  an  increase  of 
formal  private  sector  firms  by  15%  per  year.  As  SMEs  are 
overwhelmingly the dominant business form in Lao PDR, sound policy

ii 
 
suggests that they should be treated as the private sector norm and not 
the exception. This further suggests that the reform agenda should be 
broad-based, focusing on reducing transaction costs and improving the 
predictability of the investment climate. Reforms supporting institutional 
development in SME policy formulation and implementation, access to 
finance,  strengthening  the  investment  climate,  completing  the 
unfinished trade policy regime, and achieving macroeconomic stability 
in support of private sector growth are crucial for reducing transaction 
costs, expanding the private sector, putting economic growth on a more 
sustainable path, and contributing to poverty reduction. These reforms 
are being pursued in the context of a resource export boom that will 
provide  the  Government  with  the  fiscal  space  to  achieve  its 
development goals. Lao PDR’s increasing regional and global market 
integration will create new opportunities and challenges for its private 
sector. 
The Government has implemented a series of investment reforms aimed 
at reducing the cost of doing business in the country. The Government is 
also  committed  to  preparing  for  World  Trade  Organization  (WTO) 
accession talks. This process will influence the way Lao PDR thinks 
about its business climate and trade policy over the medium term. At the 
same time, the Government has introduced measures to address the 
fiscal imbalance, resulting in a gradual reduction in the fiscal deficit, 
improved macroeconomic stability, and greater investor confidence in 
2005 and 2006. The program cluster supports the Government’s efforts 
to create an enabling environment for the private sector in four target 
areas:  (i)  institutional  development  in  SME  policy  formulation  and 
implementation, and access to finance; (ii) investment climate; (iii) trade 
policy  and  capacity;  and  (iv)  macroeconomic  stability  in  support  of 
private  sector  growth.  A  joint  team  of  representatives  from  the 
Government and ADB prepared the reform program. 
   
Impact and  The program cluster aims to support the Government in its efforts to 
Outcome  expand the private sector, while reducing poverty and creating more 
jobs. To achieve these objectives, the program cluster will undertake 
the following strategic reforms: 
 
(i)  Improve the institutional framework for SME policy formulation and 
implementation, SME access to finance through better accounting 
rules  and  guidelines  for  taxation,  development  of  nonbank 
financial  instruments,  and  increased  transparency  of  the 
regulatory environment affecting SMEs. 
(ii)  Improve the investment climate by (a) enacting and implementing 
the Enterprise Law to enhance the legal and regulatory framework 
for investments; and (b) implementing other policy reforms aimed 
at reducing transaction costs in Lao PDR. 
(iii)  Strengthen  trade  policy  and  capacity  by  reforming  the  import-
export  management  system,  and  by  strengthening  indigenous 
capacity to carry out trade policy analysis to enable the country to 
effectively continue reforms and participate in the WTO process.

iii 
(iv)  Maintain the macroeconomic stability necessary for private sector  
growth and development by continuing to make progress towards 
fiscal  consolidation,  thereby  achieving  price  stability  and  a 
competitive exchange rate. 
   
Financing Plan  As proposed, ADB will provide a grant of $5 million from its Special 
Funds  resources  for  subprogram  1  of  the  Private  Sector  and  SME 
Development Program cluster with terms and conditions set forth in the 
draft Grant Agreement. 
   
Program Period and  The program cluster period is from November 2005 to December 2009. 
Tranche Release  A single tranche grant of $5 million will be disbursed under subprogram 
1  when  the  Government  has  met  the  conditions  for  effectiveness. 
Subprogram 2, which will not exceed $5 million, will be submitted for 
Board consideration about 24 months after subprogram 1 becomes 
effective, subject to the Government’s readiness to continue with its 
reform  agenda.  November  2005  was  selected  as  the  starting  point 
because it coincided with the commencement of the project preparatory 
technical assistance for the SME program and the enactment of the 
Enterprise Law. Further, it reflects the period of ADB’s engagement and 
dialogue with the Government on business climate reforms embedded 
in the cluster program.  
   
Counterpart Funds  The  Government  will  use  the  local  currency  counterpart  funds 
generated by the grant proceeds to meet program expenditures and 
associated costs of reform, and to help maintain current levels of social 
expenditure. 
   
Executing Agency   The  Ministry  of  Industry  and  Commerce  (MOIC)  is  the  Executing 
Agency. MOIC will be responsible for coordinating the implementation 
of the PSME reforms and sustaining them. 
   
Implementation  The Ministry of Finance (MOF) and the Committee for Planning and 
Arrangements  Investment (CPI) are the Implementing Agencies. MOIC will establish a 
PSME  steering  committee,  chaired  by  the  minister  of  industry  and 
commerce,  comprising  senior  officials  from  MOF  and  CPI.  The 
committee  will  meet  quarterly  to  monitor  progress  and  oversee  the 
implementation of the cluster program, and to provide guidance and 
direction to MOIC, MOF, and CPI.  
   
Procurement   The grant proceeds will be used to finance the full foreign exchange 
costs (excluding local duties and taxes) of items produced and procured 
in  ADB  member  countries,  excluding  ineligible  items  and  imports 
financed by other bilateral and multilateral sources.  
 
Program Benefits  The program cluster will provide the following benefits: 
and Beneficiaries  (i)  Improved investor confidence through enhanced implementation 
of the Enterprise Law, and well as synchronization of the positive 
list  of  sectors  open  to  foreign  investment  under  the  foreign 
investment  law  with  the  negative  list  of  sectors  closed  to 
registration under the Enterprise Law.

iv 
 
(ii)  Lower  transaction  costs  for  business  because  of  streamlined 
business start-up procedures, reduced regulations (red tape), and 
reform of the remaining nontariff barriers. 
(iii)  Strengthened institutional development by raising the capabilities 
of MOIC, MOF, and CPI to carry out policy analysis. The posting 
of  regulations  on  the  Small  and  Medium-sized  Enterprises 
Promotions and Development Office (SMEPDO) website also will 
contribute to institutional development through better regulatory 
transparency. The new SME strategy provides a comprehensive, 
integrated  approach  to  private  sector  policy  and  coordination 
across relevant line ministries. 
(iv)  Support for the Government’s efforts to reduce poverty through 
reforms  aimed  at  expanding  the  private  sector  as  a  major 
generator of new jobs and incomes by opening new economic 
opportunities and raising productivity. 
(v)  Progress toward fiscal consolidation, which will help foster broad-
based economic growth, job creation, and poverty reduction. 
   
Risks and  The cluster program is embedded in SEDP6, the Government’s new 
Assumptions  SME strategy, and ongoing business climate reforms. The assumptions 
underlying the program include the following:   
(i)  Macroeconomic  stability  and  the  resource  export  boom  will 
continue. 
(ii)  The  economy  will  be  able  to  withstand  external  or  domestic 
shocks. 
(iii)  The Government will stay on course with key business climate 
policy reform measures and fiscal consolidation.  
 
However, the program faces the following risks: 
(i)  In transitional economies, maintaining macroeconomic stability—
reflected, for example, in slow inflation and a stable exchange 
rate—is  essential  for  investor  confidence  and  private  sector 
growth.  Lao  PDR  is  particularly  vulnerable  to  macroeconomic 
instability due to weak institutions. In addition, the country is facing 
emerging fiscal and macroeconomic challenges in the context of 
its  resource  export  boom,  and  the  associated  volatile  and 
unpredictable nature of commodity prices. 
(ii)  Weak coordination among Government agencies. However, the 
Government  appears  strongly  committed  to  the  PSME  reform 
program, which is embedded in SEDP6, and the Government’s 
SME  Strategy.  A  committee  has  been  established  to  oversee 
implementation of the cluster program. The cluster program also 
limits the number of implementing agencies to two, in addition to 
MOIC.  
(iii)  A lack of resources and other emerging priorities during 2008 and 
2009  might  constrain  the  capacity  of  agencies  to  implement 
reforms.  The  proposed  JSF  grant  is  designed  to  support  the 
implementation  of  the  policy  triggers  in  subprogram  2.  The 
European Commission (EC) will provide parallel financing of about 
€3 million for additional technical assistance (TA) to support the 
implementation of the cluster program, as well as to broaden its

v 
reform agenda. The EC-funded TA is expected to be mobilized in 
September  2007.  Many  other  development  partners  also  are 
supporting private sector reforms through TA: Australian Agency 
for International Development (AusAID), European Commission 
(EC),  German  development  cooperation  through  Deutsche 
Gesellschaft  für  Technische  Zusammenarbeit  (GTZ),  Japan 
International Cooperation Agency (JICA), and World Bank. 
(iv)  Vested interests might resist the reforms. Reforms to the import-
export management system and institutionalization of economic 
governance reforms—i.e., red tape review process—are likely to 
be long, drawn out processes. However, several factors mitigate 
these risks. First, the strategic approach of the program cluster is 
to focus efforts on supporting the Government’s initiatives to (a) 
complete the unfinished trade policy agenda; (b) begin tackling the 
myriad licenses hurting firms, including enterprise registration and 
operating licenses; and (c) create an enabling environment for 
SMEs, as articulated in its SME strategy. Second, reforms will 
focus on areas where there is political will, some capacity, and 
traction.  This  has  been  demonstrated  by  enacting  the  new 
Enterprise Law, which promises to ensure enterprise registration 
within  10  days  and  the  introduction  of  the  negative  list  for 
activities. The predictability and transparency of the investment 
climate has improved as a result.   
   
Technical  The proposed advisory TA to support the cluster program is estimated 
Assistance  to cost $690,000. ADB will finance $550,000 through a grant from JSF. 
 
The  TA  will  support  MOIC,  MOF,  and  CPI  in  implementing  and 
monitoring key policy reforms, particularly those to broaden and deepen 
the  private  sector  policy  reform  agenda  during  the  cluster  program 
period, as well as those to provide the Government with timely, policy 
advice  on  demand  basis.  The  TA  has  six  components.  Under 
component 1, it will support the streamlining of business registration 
procedures and assist in establishing the business registry information 
management  system  within  the  national  Government  and  in  four 
provinces. The TA will provide training before rolling out systems to 
other provinces. Under component 2, it will assist the Government in 
streamlining  and  simplifying  import-export  procedures,  analyzing  the 
costs of the import-controlled system for a selection of commodities, 
designing a strategy for reforming the system consistent with WTO 
rules, and improving access to trade data. Component 3 will strengthen 
analytical support for the Government’s continuing efforts to improve its 
trade policy regime. This will include estimating the effective rates of 
protection to help the Government assess the effects of the trade policy 
agenda on resource allocation, and in-house training programs on trade 
policy  analysis.  Under  component  4,  the  TA  will  support  the 
Government’s  efforts  to  carry  out  a  survey  of  red  tape,  including 
quantifying  the  costs  of  complying  with  regulations,  and  devise  a 
strategy for institutionalizing a continuous review of red tape. It also will 
support  SMEPDO  in  strengthening  the  SME  policy  framework  and 
regulatory transparency, for example, by encouraging the posting of

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
program cluster to the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) for the Private Sector and 
Small  and  Medium-Sized  Enterprises  (SME)  Development  Program  cluster  (the  program 
cluster), comprising two subprograms; and (ii) a proposed grant to Lao PDR for subprogram 1 of 
the program cluster. The program cluster supports a policy reform program prepared by a joint 
team of representatives from the Government of Lao PDR and the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB). This report also describes proposed technical assistance (TA) for strengthening the 
development of the private sector and SMEs. If the Board approves the proposed grant, I, acting 
under the authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA. The program design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  THE PROGRAM AND MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 
A.  Development Strategies and the Lao PDR Socio-Economic Development Plan 
2.  In 2004, the Government announced its poverty reduction strategy (PRS) and reaffirmed 
that eradicating poverty and accelerating the pace of social development are the country’s most 
important long-term strategic goals. The PRS describes the Government’s plans to help the 
country meet the Millennium Development Goals (MDG) by 2015 by fostering economic growth 
with  equity,  sociocultural  development,  and  sustainable  environmental  preservation.  The 
national poverty reduction effort prioritizes agriculture, health, education, and infrastructure. The 
PRS has been mainstreamed into the Sixth Socio-Economic Development Plan 2006–2010,1 or 
SEDP6, which sets out the country’s development priorities, policy agenda, programs, and 
projects. The five pillars of SEDP6 are to (i) achieve faster and more sustainable economic 
growth,  and  to  create  jobs  through  private  sector  development  (PSD)  that  emphasizes 
commercial agriculture, rural development, infrastructure development, and SMEs; (ii) improve 
the provision of basic social services, focusing on health, education, and clean drinking water; 
(iii) strengthen human security, including through measures to improve food security, reduce 
threats  from  unexploded  ordnance,  and  ensure  protection  against  natural  disasters;  (iv) 
enhance participation by empowering the poor; and (v) develop the poorest areas through a 
range of targeted interventions (Figure 1). The SEDP6 approach is an improvement on the 
previous  sector-based  planning  approach,  which  emphasized  setting  quantitative  targets. 
Although SEDP6 still has these targets, it focuses more on the identification of crosscutting 
policy issues and strategies to ensure a more integrated development policy framework.  
 
3.  SEDP6  identifies  crosscutting  strategies  for  fostering  PSD.  Continuing  reforms  to 
improve  the  investment  climate,  regional  integration,  macroeconomic  stability,  and  good 
governance are considered key crosscutting issues for PSD. Continuing reforms to the business 
regulatory  environment,  promoting  foreign  direct  investment  (FDI),  and  developing  new 
infrastructure are measures intended to improve the investment climate. Meanwhile, reducing 
trade barriers, promoting cross-border investment, and encouraging membership in regional 
economic associations and agreements are measures aimed at increasing the integration of the 
domestic market with the global economy.

B.  The Government and its ADB Partnership 
4.  The proposed PSME grants will support the broad priorities of the Government’s private 
sector and SME development agenda, including institutional strengthening, as highlighted in the 
development policy letter addressed to the President of ADB (Appendix 2). These broad areas 
include (i) institutional development in SME policy formulation and implementation, and access 
to  finance;  (ii)  investment  climate;  (iii)  trade  policy  and  capacity  building;  and  (iv) 
macroeconomic stability in support of private sector growth (Figure 2). The close alignment 
between  the  Government’s  reform  agenda  and  the  program  cluster  will  strengthen  its 
commitment to the reforms under the program cluster.  
 
5.  The Medium-Term Programmatic Approach. The proposed program cluster provides 
(i) a coherent reform strategy with two discrete but linked subprograms; (ii) a strong emphasis 
on performance, as the decision on whether to proceed with the next subprogram depends on 
satisfactory  achievement  of  five  “triggers”;  and  (iii)  flexibility  in  the  reform  measures,  with 
provisions  for  incorporating  lessons  learned  and  responding  to  changes  in  the  external 
environment in the design of subsequent subprograms. The proposed program cluster for Lao 
PDR is modeled on recent ADB programs for the Philippines, such as the Development Policy 
Support  Program.2 The  key  features  of  this  program  include  (i)  a  series  of  single-tranche 
operations, with a well-defined, medium-term framework specified at the outset, and including 
completed  high-impact  reforms  before  Board  consideration;  (ii)  triggers  for  subsequent 
subprograms to ensure continual dialogue among the Government, ADB, and stakeholders; and 
(iii) a small number of well-targeted policy actions designed to achieve high-impact outcomes in 
priority sectors. The program cluster for Lao PDR includes a small number of high-impact policy 
reforms to the business climate, while focusing on strengthening institutional capacity with 
attention to positive outcomes for efficient SME development and growth.  
 
6.  Subprogram 1 of the program cluster, financed with a grant of $5 million from ADB’s 
Special Funds resources, focuses on legislative reforms to the enterprise registration regime 
and begins the process for SME policy and institutional strengthening, while also targeting trade 
policy reforms. It will establish the basis for continual policy dialogue and engagement during 
2007–2009 (subprogram 2).  
 
7.  Subprogram  2,  which  is  not  to  exceed  $5  million  in  financing,  will  continue  the 
momentum of the reforms in subprogram 1. In addition to implementing investment climate 
reforms and SME institutional development, subprogram 2 will support the Government’s efforts 
to improve trade policy capacity, especially as Lao PDR prepares for World Trade Organization 
(WTO) accession. Further, subprogram 2 will address key risks identified in subprogram 1, as 
well as make progress in other areas that might emerge from policy dialogue and engagement 
with the Government in 2008 and 2009. The expected time frame for processing subprogram 2 
(2 years after subprogram 1 becomes effective) is only indicative. Subprogram 2 contains a 
limited number of specific reform actions (five triggers) to provide the flexibility needed to 
respond to unanticipated changes in the external environment by framing an appropriate policy 
response. This approach will ensure the program cluster is synchronized with the Government’s 
policy agenda in an environment of rapidly changing policy priorities.

8.  Country Strategy and Program (CSP). PSD is a theme of the CSP for 2007–2011.3 
The CSP emphasizes that ADB will help the Government to improve the climate for PSD 
through a combination of technical support for policy, institutional, and regulatory reform in key 
sectors where ADB operates. It seeks to transform agriculture sector from a subsistence to a 
commercial  orientation,  improve  basic  transport  and  power  infrastructure,  strengthen  the 
regulatory  regime  governing  financial  institutions,  restructure  the  commercial  state  banks, 
improve investment regulations, foster SME growth, mobilize resources and broaden access to 
financing for PSD, and enhance the soundness and sustainability of public finance.  
 
9.  The CSP 2007–2011 has established two performance indicators for PSD: (i) increase 
formal private enterprises by 15% per year, and (ii) reduce the number of days needed to start a 
business. For effective development results, the program cluster will focus on four core areas 
directly affecting private sector development and growth, and specifically SMEs: institutional 
development in SME policy formulation and implementation, investment climate, trade policy 
and capacity building, and macroeconomic stability—all of which are key outcomes and outputs 
of the CSP (footnote 3). The program cluster complements ADB’s other PSD-related sector

III.  THE SECTOR 
A.  Review of the Economy, Investment Climate, and Poverty 
11.  Sustained Economic Growth in 2006 and 2007. The Lao PDR economy continues to 
expand strongly. Growth has accelerated from 6.9% in 2004, to 7.2% in 2005, and to an 
estimated 7.3% in 2006. The current growth rate is well above the average of 6% per year from 
1990 to 2003. The data in Table 1 on key indicators for 2002–2006 show the recovery and 
restoration of macroeconomic stability after the economic crisis in 1998–1999. Robust growth in 
2006  occurred  across  all  major  sectors,  led  by  mining  and  power,  followed  closely  by 
manufacturing, and then services and agriculture. Industry and services accounted for 80% of 
economic growth in 2005 compared with about 50% of growth in 2000. In 2006, exports of 
goods and services increased by more than 50% from 2005 levels on the back of a surge in 
commodity prices combined with a huge jump in copper and gold production. Tourism is doing 
well. More than 1 million foreigners visited Lao PDR in 2005, a record, generating an estimated 
$147 million in revenue and helping to fuel a construction boom in the capital, Vientiane, and 
another major tourist destination, Luang Prabang. Visitor arrivals are estimated to reach 1.2 
million in 2006 (Appendix 5). Sales of domestic cement and other construction materials, along 
with imports of capital goods, suggest investment growth is strong. Foreign investment outside 
the  mining  sector  is  increasing,  paced  by  investments  in  sectors  where  Lao  PDR  has  a 
comparative advantage (tourism and commercial agriculture). Foreigners have made several 
important equity investments in relatively large domestic enterprises, including the Australia 
New Zealand bank’s (ANZ) purchase of Vientiane Commercial Bank and Carlsberg’s purchase 
of equity in Laobeer.  
 
12.  Stable Macroeconomic Conditions. Keeping the inflation rate under 10% has been a 
major challenge for Lao PDR authorities. The country experienced hyperinflation in 1998 and 
1999 with prices rising by more than 200% over these 2 years. Authorities tightened the money 
supply, slowing inflation to 23% in 2000. Inflation has been kept at about 10% or less since then, 
except in 2003 when a drought drove up food prices. In 2006, inflation slowed to a historical 
year-end low of 4.5%, and averaged 6.5% for the year. Inflation averaged about 4.3% for the 
first 6 months of 2007. Controlling inflation is necessary to create a stable environment for long-
term investment. Rapid inflation hurts the poor the most, because food accounts for about 50% 
of household their expenditures. The current account deficit has widened to 14% of gross 
domestic product (GDP) primarily due to imports of capital goods associated with large projects 
that will generate substantial exports and foreign currency in the next 2–5 years.

13.  Government’s Improving Fiscal Management. In 2001, Lao PDR emerged from a 
serious economic and fiscal crisis. From 1997 to 2000, budget revenues dropped significantly, 
leading to suppressed social sector spending and a substantial decline in public sector real 
wages. The Government has restored and maintained macroeconomic stability through fiscal 
discipline.  In  2006,  budget  revenues  exceeded  the  budget  plan  by  about  5%  because  of 
intensified efforts to broaden the tax base and higher collections from the booming tourism and 
mining sectors. Overall, tax and nontax collections rose by 1.3 percentage points of GDP. Early 
indications are that revenues might surpass targets in the 2007 budget. As a result, the overall 
budget deficit has declined steadily from 5.7% of GDP in 2003 to 3.4% in 2004, 3.3% in 2005, 
and 3.1% in 2006 (better than the Government’s fiscal targets for 2006). Until recently, the 
Government has restrained spending, supporting the reduction in the budget deficit. However, 
recurrent expenditures are rising in step with revenues.

8     
 
14.  Employment in the Formal Sector Expanding.  As the National Statistics Center (NSC) 
does not carry out an annual household labor force survey, tracking employment growth and 
other labor market outcomes is difficult. Every 10 years, NSC does carry out a population and 
household census that collects data on employment. The most recent census in 2005 estimated 
the workforce at 2.7 million workers, of which 2.4 million (89%) are in the informal sector (i.e., 
own account workers and unpaid family workers, mainly in agriculture). Of the estimated formal 
workers, about 30% work in the private sector (i.e., nongovernment and state-owned enterprise 
sector). The Ministry of Industry and Commerce (MOIC) carries out an annual survey of industry 
and handicraft establishments. The 2004 survey reported 102,000 workers, up from 72,000 in 
1999 (Appendix 5). As the private sector has expanded since then, current private sector 
employment would be expected to be much higher than the 2004 figure. With 80%–90% of the 
population in the informal sector, and 50% of the population under 20 years old, the challenge 
for the Government will be to support faster growth and development of the private sector as the 
main generator of new jobs over the coming decade.  
   
15.  Remarkable  Progress  in  Reducing  Poverty.  Using  the  national  poverty  line,  the 
incidence of poverty in Lao PDR has declined from 46% in 1992 to 33% in 2003. Two thirds of 
the decline in the poverty rate took place as the economy began to recover from the financial 
crisis of the late 1990s, and much of this reduction came from the poorest parts of the country. 
Factors contributing to this remarkable reduction in poverty incidence include sustained per 
capita  income  expansion,  greater  labor  mobility  between  rural  and  urban  areas  (and 
urbanization), higher rice production, private sector expansion, and improvements in market 
access internally and to neighboring countries. Lao PDR is on track to meet the MDG for 
income poverty by 2015. Poverty is primarily rural, with the incidence of poverty twice as high as 
in urban areas. Average incomes in Lao PDR are low, with per capita GDP estimated at $490 in 
2005 using current prices. However, income inequality is also low as indicated by a Gini index 
(measure of income inequality) of 33%. This reflects Lao PDR’s stage of development, in which 
subsistence agriculture remains dominant, and the fairly equitable access to land.   
 
B.  Issues and Opportunities 
16.  The  Dominance  of  Micro,  Small,  and  Medium-Sized  Enterprises  in  the  Private 
Sector. The 2001 survey of manufacturing establishments by MOIC provides the most recent 
data on the number and size of firms.6 The survey found 600–700 firms with more than 10 
employees, of which only 116 had more than 100 employees. The bulk of establishments––
about 24,000––are micro- and small enterprises with less than 10 workers. This pattern of size 
distribution in the economy is typical for small, low-income developing economies. In the initial 
stages of development, small-scale enterprises dominate the private sector. As the economy 
expands, competitive firms grow into larger firms. Findings from a recent GTZ survey of 390 
registered establishments in 2005 indicate that these growth dynamics are occurring in the 
economy (Appendix 5). At the same time, the dominance of SMEs and the informality of this 
business form also reflect the weak regulatory and institutional environment in which they 
operate. 
 
17.  Potential  for  Private  Sector  Growth  and  Development.  Various  measures  of 
productivity and trade facilitation costs, as well as large investments in infrastructure, suggest 
the conditions for growth of the economy are improving gradually (Appendix 5). The improved 
efficiency of the Lao PDR economy—located beside the two fastest-growing economies in the

1.  Need for Institutional Development on SME Policy and Access to Finance 
18.  Weak  Institutional  Policy  Making  and  Coordination.  Numerous  Government 
agencies formulate policies and regulations affecting the private sector, particularly SMEs. This 
has resulted in weak policy formulation across agencies. The Government is addressing these 
issues in a number of ways. In 2004, the Government issued a Prime Minister Office (PMO) 
decree  establishing  the  SME  Promotion  and  Development  Office  (SMEPDO),  an  agency 
attached  to  the  MOIC  and  reporting  to  the  SME  Promotion  and  Development  Committee 
(SMEPDC). SMEPDC, comprising senior officials from relevant line ministries, promotes more 
effective coordination and implementation of policies affecting the private sector. At the same 
time, SMEPDO has been mandated to develop a comprehensive national strategy to ensure an 
integrated and consistent approach to PSD (para. 51). 
 
19.  Lack of Public Information on Regulations and SME Statistics. The private sector 
has limited accessibility to information on regulations, because many Government agencies do 
not publish or post all regulations and instructions on their websites in a user-friendly way. This 
creates an uncertain and unpredictable environment for investors. In addition, policy makers 
have access to limited data on the private sector, as statistics are updated infrequently and 
generally are considered unreliable. A good system for gathering and disseminating regulatory, 
market, and other information is needed to support effective policy making. 
 
20.  SME Access to Credit. The finance sector of the Lao PDR economy is shallow, with the 
banking system constituting the only form of formal financial intermediation. Consequently, 
SMEs have had limited access to formal sources of financing, and generally rely on retained 
earnings and informal sources. The Government, with assistance from ADB through BSRP and 
RFSDP loans, is gradually restoring the health of the banking sector, improving the competitive 
environment,  and  developing  microfinance  institutions.  SMEs  face  legal  and  capacity 
constraints in accessing credit, and these need to be addressed if SMEs are going to benefit 
from recent banking sector developments. The constraints include weak protection of creditors’ 
rights, which means that banks’ rely on land and buildings as collateral to secure loans, which is 
generally biased against SMEs. The Government is addressing this through amendments to the 
secured transaction law in 2005, and is drafting an implementing decree under the BSRP. An 
operational secured transaction law creates a framework for securing movables as collateral for 
loans. Another constraint is the absence of other finance products, such as lease financing. The 
Bank of Lao PDR is drafting a decree on lease financing with assistance from ADB under the 
BSRP. It is expected to be issued at the end of 2007. 
 
21.  Poor Accounting and Financial Reporting Capacity of SMEs. Most businesses are 
unable to prepare reliable and meaningful financial statements for a loan application, or lack 
collateral, making it difficult for banks to assess borrowers’ capacity and willingness to repay.

The chart of accounts provided by the country’s current accounting procedures is too detailed 
and complicated, imposing high operational costs. As a consequence, most firms use no system 
at all, or record cash receipts and cash payments only, which provides no basis for credit risk 
assessment. The ADB-World Bank investment climate survey carried out in 20057 found that 
small entrepreneurs complain about the arbitrariness of tax assessment, and owners often need 
to negotiate with tax officials, which leads to the unequal application of tax rates. This arises in 
part because tax accounting rules appear to be complicated and are less understood by smaller 
entrepreneurs.  
 
2.  Investment Climate    
22.   Updating  and  Modernizing  Commercial  Legislation.  The  Government  has  made 
significant progress in creating a more conducive business environment by (i) enacting the new 
Enterprise Law in April 2006, (ii) amending the foreign and domestic investment laws in 2004 
and issuing implementing decrees in 2005, (iii) amending the tax and secured transactions laws 
in  2005,  and  (iv)  issuing  the  SME  decree  in  2004.  The  National  Assembly  passed  the 
Commercial Banking Law in December 2006, and enacted the Accounting Law and the State 
Audit Law in July 2007.  
 
23.  Businesses Constraints. The ADB–World Bank 2005 investment climate survey of 303 
establishments in six sectors and seven provinces reported several major constraints (Figure 3). 
The  main  constraints  for  all  establishments  involve  infrastructure,  regulation,  taxation, 
macroeconomic stability, and access to finance. The ranking of the constraints differed across 
major sectors. Manufacturing firms ranked infrastructure, regulation, and taxation as the top 
three constraints, while tourism operators ranked infrastructure, inadequate skills, and taxation 
as  the  major  constraints.  More  than  30%  of  firms  on  average  said  regulatory  policy 
uncertainty—the uneven interpretation of laws and regulations—was a severe constraint to their 
business.  The  survey  also  found  that,  because  of  too  much  regulation,  inspections  by 
government officials appear to be excessive. Most inspections came from the forest, customs, 
and tax departments, plus the economic police. The IFC Doing Business report for 20068 found 
that nine steps are required to launch a business (a hypothetical manufacturing firm) in Lao 
PDR, similar to the regional average of eight steps. However, it takes more than three times 
longer in Lao PDR to accomplish them (163 days compared to the regional average of 51 days). 
In comparison, Malaysia takes 30 days, Thailand 33 days, Viet Nam 50 days, Philippines 50 
days, Cambodia 86, and Indonesia 97 days. A recent GTZ survey of enterprises9 found a much 
shorter time to register a business than IFC reported—65% of respondent firms in the GTZ 
survey reported that it took less than 30 days to get their investment license and certificate of 
registration, and only 14% of firms reported needing more than 90 days to start a business. The 
survey did find considerable variation in the number of days required to launch a business 
across firms of different sizes, suggesting considerable uncertainty and unpredictability in the 
registration process.10

24.  Cumbersome  Registration  Procedures. To register a business, several steps are 
required involving several agencies depending on the sector. Excessive documentation also is 
involved. An investor prepares a wide range of documentation that will be required to obtain the 
necessary licenses and certificates, including a feasibility study or business plan, curriculum 
vitae  of  the  owner,  professional  certificates  of  future  staff,  shareholders’  agreement,  and 
evidence of commercial premises or location (Figure 4). The process is unpredictable, because 
sector ministries can attach additional conditions before approving the investment license. This 
has discouraged entrepreneurs from formalizing their businesses. Many transitional economies 
have moved away from approval to pure registration to facilitate the transition from a planned 
economy to a market economy. Investors are only required to register the business if the 
investment  is  not  in  a  sector  on  the  negative  list.  In  addition,  international  best  practice 
highlights the need for transparent and simple-to-follow registration procedures. 
 
25.  Modernizing  the  Business  Licensing  Process.  In  2006,  the  Government  made 
effective the Enterprise Law, replacing the Business Law of 1994. The new law, which aims to 
streamline registration procedures, mandates the registration of enterprises not on the negative 
list within 10 days. Implementation of the Enterprise Law is essential, and the PSME program 
cluster includes a series of policy actions to implement this legislative reform. Other important 
reforms involved amendments to the Foreign Investment Law and the Domestic Investment Law 
in 2004. The two laws are important milestones in Lao PDR’s transition to an open market 
economy, as they establish a broad framework to promote investment.11 A major weakness of 
the Foreign Investment Law is the positive list for investment, which allows foreigners to invest 
in only those sectors listed as “open” to foreign investment or “open with conditions”. Most 
countries have shifted away from using a positive list for foreign investment to a negative list, as 
it improves certainty in the investment regime. To ensure investor certainty and transparency,

26.  Business  Registry  Information  System.  The  information  system  for  operating  a 
business registry office is inadequate and does not function properly outside the main industrial 
centers. About 77,000 registered firms are listed with the Department of Domestic Trade (DDT) 
at MOIC in Vientiane. However, the provinces do not provide systematic updates, primarily

the office only has one computer and limited access to the Internet. The Government must 
address the information technology constraints in the major provinces to allow the effective 
implementation of the provincial and national business registry system under the new Enterprise

distribution. A systematic and central database that can gather and disseminate information of 
registered enterprises would add significant value to doing business by providing information 
useful to the private sector. It also would allow the tax department to update its database of 
taxpayers regularly.

31). The Government lacks a system for reviewing laws and regulations affecting licensing and 
inspection to determine their impact on the private sector. As a result, the regulatory compliance 
costs imposed on the private sector are not appreciated.

3.  Trade Policy and Capacity  
28.    Under the trading system adopted in the late 1970s, the level and composition of trade 
was effectively controlled through quantitative restrictions and state-owned trading companies. 
Tariffs and trade taxes played little or no role other then as a means to collect revenue. A 
process of market-oriented reforms began in the late 1980s, including a reduction in customs 
duties and elimination of most nontariff barriers. As a consequence, the average customs duty 
has fallen to about 10%, among the lowest in the region. 
 
29.  Administrative and Nontariff Barriers to Trade Remain. Nontariff barriers have been 
relaxed gradually, beginning with the introduction of the New Economic Mechanism in 1986. 
This  process  is  continuing.  The  International  Monetary  Fund  (IMF)  Index  of  Trade 
Restrictiveness  shows  that,  while  tariffs  are  relatively  low,  nontariff  barriers  are  relatively 
restrictive compared to other countries in the region.

30.  Import Licensing and Administrative Procedures Are the Main Nontariff Barriers. 
Lao  PDR  operates  an  import-export  management  and  control  system  identical  to  the  one 
operated in Viet Nam until recently. The system has two key features. The first feature is the 
classification of imports into three categories: (i) prohibited goods,12 (ii) controlled goods, and (iii) 
general goods that are easily imported. Prohibited goods include many products related to 
public  safety,  environment,  and  morals,  and  not  to  protection  of  domestic  producers.  The 
controlled  category  deals  with  nonautomatic  licenses  for  imports  that  are  not  banned  but 
managed by MOIC. Items on this list were defined broadly. Until October 2006, these included 
about 25 broad items, such as prepared foods and all raw and semi-manufactured products 
used in manufacturing. The broad classification of imports provided trade and customs officials 
with discretion in determining whether an import item should be on the list and subject to a 
nonautomatic import license. Little empirical work has been done examining the extent to which 
the import management mechanism has restricted imports for protection purposes. In reforming 
the import and export management system, MOIC has made significant advances in 2006 and 
2007 in an effort to reduce trade facilitation costs. The list of items on the controlled list was 
revised in October 2006. One important change to the list has been the improvement in its 
transparency. MOIC has classified 80% of the items on the list according to the 6- to 8-digit 
harmonized code (HS),  instead of the previous practice of using the 2- to 4-digit harmonized 
code.  This  reform  has  substantially  reduced  trade  and  customs  officials  with  discretion  in 
determining whether an item should be on the list and subject to a nonautomatic import license.

the  import-export  management  system  is  the  requirement  that,  until  March  2007,  all 
producers/importers must produce an import plan for the year. MOIC and local authorities must

32.  Government  Considers  WTO  Accession  a  Foreign  Trade  Policy  Priority.  The 
Government is beginning preparations to apply for WTO membership. Its third working party 
meeting is planned for November 2007. Lao PDR’s preparation for WTO accession talks will

this regard, MOIC is looking at ways to accelerate reforms to the import management system. It 
intends to continue to reduce the number of sectors on the controlled list, as well as streamline 
and simplify import and export procedures and regulations. The WTO accession efforts build on 
Lao PDR’s commitments to the Common Effective Preferential Tariff (CEPT) schedule under 
the ASEAN Free Trade Agreement (AFTA). Lao PDR will phase in the inclusion list (items that 
will have a tariff of 5% or less) in 2008, phase in the temporary exclusion list also by 2008, and

33.  Strengthening Trade Policy Capacity. The institutional arrangements and processes 
for  making  trade  policy  are  just  as  important  as  reforms  to  the  trade  policy  regime.  The 
Department of Foreign Trade Policy at MOIC sets the broad trade policy framework and agenda, 
and is taking the lead in WTO preparations and AFTA. The department, with 30 staff members, 
is overstretched. It also lacks the resources needed to carry out adequate trade policy analysis 
that is essential for making the case for further trade reforms and effective participation in WTO. 
At the same time, several agencies of Government are involved in setting trade policy. Besides 
the Department of Foreign Trade Policy, the Department of Export and Import Management sets 
import  and  export  procedures,  and  compiles  the  controlled  import  list.  Import  licensing  in 
individual sectors is controlled by the Department of Agriculture; the Ministry of Health; Ministry 
of Communication, Transport, Post and Construction; as well as MOIC. Ensuring consistency of 
trade  policy  across  the  government  will  be  a  challenge,  as  in  most  countries.  While  the 
Government considers WTO accession important for its integration efforts, it also must build the 
capacity to carry out analysis of policy on its merits for Lao PDR. This requires significant 
capacity  building  within  the  Department  of  Foreign  Trade  Policy,  MOIC,  and  other  related 
agencies.  
 
4.  Macroeconomic Stability for Private Sector Growth 
34.  Maintaining macroeconomic stability will be important to support growth of the private 
sector operating in the nonresource segment of the economy.  
 
35.  Private Sector Growth. In Lao PDR, future developments in the resource sector will 
influence macroeconomic stability.13 The Government anticipates significant future revenues 
from hydropower investments and mining in the form of taxes, royalties, and dividends. The 
mining sector generated more than $72 million in budget revenues (about 15% of domestic 
budget revenues) in 2006, a figure that could rise to $100 million in 2007. The revenue flows 
provide  fiscal  space  and  a  tremendous  opportunity  for  Lao  PDR  to  finance  its  priority 
development goals, raise per capita incomes, and reduce poverty, as earlier resource booms 
did in Indonesia and Botswana (another small, landlocked country). At the same time, a long 
resource boom can undermine the competitiveness of the nonresource tradable goods sector 
(agriculture and manufacturing) if it leads to an excessive appreciation of the kip––i.e., where 
the appreciation cannot be justified based on economy-wide productivity growth and investment. 
The real kip exchange rate has appreciated faster than the Thai baht and other currencies in the 
region (Appendix 5). However, because macroeconomic data is limited, it is unclear whether 
this  appreciation  is  excessive  or  has  affected  competitiveness.  International  experience 
provides important lessons for Lao PDR regarding the need to maintain private sector growth 
during a resource boom. As Indonesia and Botswana have shown, (i) fiscal discipline must be 
maintained and expenditures smoothed out to avoid excessively inflationary effects of resource 
revenues flows in the economy, and (ii) business climate reforms and investments are needed 
to raise productive capacity in the tradable goods sectors (Appendix 5, para. 16;  Appendix 6, 
para. 9).14  
 
36.  Progress Towards Achieving Macroeconomic Stability. The Government is acutely 
aware  of  the  necessity  for  macroeconomic  stability  to  achieve  PSD.  In  this  context,  the 
Government (i) is making progress towards fiscal consolidation, as reflected in the reduction of 
the budget deficit to 3.1% of GDP in 2006; (ii) intends to use additional resource revenues to

37.  Challenges to Improving Fiscal Sustainability Over the Medium Term. Lao PDR has 
one of the lowest tax revenue-to-GDP ratios (about 11%–12%) among low-income countries, 
partly  because  of  the  dominance  of  subsistence  agriculture  in  the  economy.  Revenue 
management is challenged by (i) fragmented revenue administration whereby provinces are 
responsible for collecting major taxes, undermining revenue mobilization at the central level; (ii) 
proliferation of fiscal incentives under the investment laws (about 1,600 firms have incentives); 
and (iii) weak tax administration. Recent improvements in tax collection, combined with the 
boost in royalties and taxes from the mining sector, have helped address part of the problem of 
revenue mobilization. The Government is addressing these challenges on a sustainable basis 
(appendix 6). In 2006, the National Assembly enacted the new budget law, which aims to 
reconcentrate  revenue  collection.  Two  important  features  of  the  law  in  this  regard  are  (i) 
classifying revenues belonging to the central Government and provincial governments, as well 
as those to be shared between the central and provincial governments (such as excise taxes); 
and (ii) bringing the customs and tax department/treasury under the jurisdiction of the central 
Government. The Government also intends to introduce the value-added tax (VAT) in 2009. The 
World Bank and the Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency (Sida) are working 
closely with the Government to address problems associated with tax administration, particularly 
on ways to improve incentives for provinces to collect and pass on more tax revenues to the 
central Government.  
 
38.  Improving  Public  Expenditure  Management. One of the ways the Government is 
attempting  to  improve  expenditure  management  is  by  implementing  the  medium-term 
expenditure framework (MTEF). The MTEF links annual budgeting decisions to medium-term 
spending  requirements of approved programs and projects. The implementation of the MTEF 
under its public expenditure framework is in the early stages, and the Government is working 
closely with ADB and the World Bank to implement systems to improve public expenditure 
management (Appendix 6). The ADB CSP for 2006–2011 includes two TA projects in support of 
the  Government’s  public  expenditure  management:  (i)  proposed  TA  on  public  expenditure 
planning for SEDP6 in 2008, and (ii) TA for public expenditure management with Ministry of 
Finance (MOF) in 2009.  
 
39.  Macroeconomic Indicators Needed. Assessing the impact of the resource boom on 
competitiveness of the nonresource sector is difficult, partly because limited data is available on 
a timely basis. In this regard, the collection of relevant macroeconomic data is important. These 
should  include  a  series  of  tradable  and  non-tradable  price  indices  (to  estimate  the  real 
exchange rate), wage data, employment, and data on key economic activities, preferably on a 
quarterly basis (para. 91). The data would enable authorities to track the impact of any change 
in  the  real  exchange  rate  on  the  private  sector,  and  would  allow  authorities  to  adjust 
macroeconomic policy appropriately.  
 
C.  Lessons 
40.  ADB has supported PSD reforms in several areas, primarily in banking and microfinance, 
transport,  energy,  and  agriculture.  ADB  also  has  maintained  a  policy  dialogue  with  the 
Government.  Assessments  by  ADB’s  Operations  Evaluation  Department  (OED)  found  that 
ADB’s public sector operations in Lao PDR aimed at developing an enabling environment for 
PSD, largely through three financial sector programs, were partly successful. This failure to 
deliver the intended outcomes was due mainly to delayed compliance and noncompliance with

18     
 
many conditions.15 The ADB Lao PDR Resident Mission, which has tracked the percentage of 
time elapsed in 24 active loan projects since 2000, verifies implementation difficulties across the 
loan portfolio—slightly more than 60% of disbursements were met on time. Almost all the 
slippage occurs during the first year of the program, suggesting that loan tranche or subprogram 
periods should be much longer than 12 months (Figure 7).  
 
41.  This poor performance in operations provides some important lessons for policy lending 
and program design in the Lao PDR context. These include the following:  
 
(i)  Political support and macroeconomic stability is an important factor behind the 
success of a development assistance program.  
(ii)  Success requires careful program preparation, involving prior detailed analytical 
work and active consultations with stakeholders over a sufficiently long period to 
ensure adequate “buy-in” and government ownership of the program. 
(iii)  Program designs should be relatively simple. The three-tranche loan program 
mode that characterized previous and current finance sector program designs in 
Lao PDR has been too complex. Programs are likely to fail if they have been 
overloaded with policy conditions; involve complicated legislative reforms; have 
too  many  implementing  agencies,  which  the  executing  agency  has  limited 
influence  over;  and  impose  excessive  demands  on  the  already  weak 
administrative capacities of the implementing agencies. In the country assistance 
program evaluation, OED suggested that the performance of program lending 
should  be  improved  by  a  more  realistic  reform  package  consistent  with  the 
Government’s capacity, and by making future program lending more manageable 
(footnote 15).  
(iv)  Sustaining development impact requires constant policy dialogue and monitoring 
during implementation. This also requires measurable indicators that are precise 
and  clear.  The  Lao  PDR  experience  strongly  suggests  that  the  quality  and 
frequency of ADB dialogue with implementing agencies and program monitoring 
are important factors for success. 
(v)  The  success  of  the  assistance  program  depends  on  its  ability  to  nurture 
institutional  capacities.  Weak  institutions  (and  by  implication  personnel 
counterparts) often have been cited as one of the principal causes of program 
failures in Lao PDR (footnote 15). For effective development results, the policy 
agenda  needs  to  be  backed  by  focused  TA  that  emphasizes  strengthening 
institutions, particularly the analytical capacity of the implementing agency to 
implement the reforms.  
 
42.  In  light  of  these  lessons,  the  following  steps  have  been  taken  into  account  when 
designing this program cluster:16   
 
(i)  The economic, social, and political environment in which the reform agenda is 
planned, and the degree of commitment, ownership, and readiness shown by the 
Government, need to be assessed carefully.  
(ii)  The program agenda should include the flexibility to cope with emerging policy 
changes and priorities, as well as institutional weaknesses and problems.

private sector growth are likely to show more sustainable results—in terms of private sector

subsidizing BDS. This builds on the recognition that services to SMEs are private goods that are

services sector as the supplier of business services to other SMEs, improving the regulatory 
environment for SMEs to operate, improving the legal framework for collateral and nonbank

IV.  THE PROPOSED PROGRAM 
A.  Objective and Scope 
46.  The program cluster aims to support the Government in two main ways. First, it seeks to 
expand the private sector through institutional development for SME policy and access to 
finance,  a  better  investment  climate,  improved  trade  policy  and  capacity,  and  stable 
macroeconomic environment. Second, the program clusters aims to help reduce poverty and 
increase jobs through an expansion of the private sector.  
 
47.  The program cluster includes a series of policy reforms that underpin the priorities of 
SEDP6. These reforms are designed to accomplish the following:  
 
(i)  Institutional development for SME policy and access to finance by strengthening 
the  institutional  framework  for  SME  policy  formulation  and  implementation, 
expanding SME access to finance through improvements in accounting rules and 
guidelines,  developing  nonbank  financial  instruments,  and  increasing 
transparency of the regulatory environment affecting SMEs.  
(ii)  Improve the investment climate by implementing the Enterprise Law and other 
policy reforms aimed at reducing transaction costs in Lao PDR.  
(iii)  Improved trade policy and capacity by reforming the import-export management 
system,  including  making  measures  more  transparent  and  reforming  the 
controlled list of imports over the medium term, and strengthening indigenous 
capacity to carry out trade policy analysis. 
(iv)  Maintain macroeconomic stability necessary for private sector development and 
growth by continuing to make progress towards fiscal consolidation and price 
stability, and by producing timely macroeconomic indicators to track performance 
of the private sector. 
 
48.  Subprogram  1  is  designed  to  be  a  single-tranche  operation  with  a  well-defined 
framework to align with the Government’s SEDP6. Advisory TA also is proposed to support the 
deepening and implementation of reforms over the program cluster period. Consideration of 
subprogram 2 will depend on satisfactory accomplishment of five policy triggers. The design and 
monitoring framework of the program cluster is in Appendix 1. The development policy letter is 
in Appendix 2. The PSME medium-term program, including policy matrix for subprogram 1, 
triggers, and milestones for subprogram 2 are in Appendix 3. Appendix 4 presents the donor 
coordination matrix.  
 
B.  Policy Framework and Actions 
49.  All 14 policy measures required for subprogram 1 had been carried out by the end of 
August 2007. 
  
1.  Subprogram 1, Core Area 1: Institutional Development for SME Policy and 
Access to Finance 
50.  Subprogram  1  supports  the  Government’s  goals  of  establishing  the  strategic  and 
institutional framework for SME policy formulation and implementation, and improving SMEs’ 
accounting capabilities to increase access to finance. Toward achieving these objectives, two 
actions were completed before Board consideration of subprogram 1—an SME strategy was

produced (para. 51), and the National Assembly enacted an accounting law and state audit law 
(para. 52). 
 
51.  SME  Strategy.  The  Prime  Minister’s  Office  approved  the  SME  Policy  Strategy. 
SMEPDO designed the SME strategy as mandated under Prime Minister’s Decree No. 42 of 
2004. The strategy was drafted with input from international and regional experts, including from 
ADB through its SME project preparatory TA.18 It was prepared through a relatively consultative 
approach, including consultation with the business community and other stakeholders. The 
strategy provides a comprehensive action plan for assisting SMEs in addressing constraints to 
growth, including creating an enabling regulatory environment for SMEs by (i) implementing the 
Enterprise  Law  and  licensing  reforms,  (ii)  providing  business  development  support,  (iii) 
promoting improved accounting practices for SMEs with the aim of expanding access to finance, 
and (iv) providing greater transparency in taxation.  
 
52.  Accounting Law and State Audit Law. Enacted by the National Assembly in July 2007, 
the  Accounting  Law  establishes  the  framework  and  standards  that  are  consistent  with 
international ones. It will support improvements in the accounting profession and accounting 
capabilities of all enterprises. The law adopts international accounting practices and certification 
for  different  types  of  accounting  and  bookkeeping  professions.  The auditing  provisions  for 
private companies are included in the Audit Law, also enacted in July 2007. The law provides 
for defining standards for smaller enterprises, which would be simpler to follow. Its adoption will 
improve  SMEs’  accounting  practices  and  their  financial  reporting  capacities,  which  are 
necessary to improve their access to finance. Subprogram 2 supports the implementation of the 
law on accounting, including MOF’s issuing of guidelines for SME accounting practices, and 
defining the criteria for enterprises that must adopt the new accounting standards. Subprogram 
2 also includes measures to improve access to finance by improving the legal framework for 
secured transactions and lease financing (para. 63). 
 
2.  Subprogram 1, Core Area 2: Investment Climate 
53.  Subprogram  1  supports  the  Government’s  agenda  to  improve  the  regulatory 
environment for investments and private sector growth. The main objective is to expand the 
number of private enterprises (and therefore investment). Reform areas of critical significance 
targeted under subprogram 1 include implementing the new Law of Enterprises, as well as other 
policy reforms aimed at reducing transaction costs. The following measures (para. 54–57) 
toward achieving these objectives were completed before Board consideration of subprogram 1. 
 
54.  The New Enterprise Law. In 2006, the Government made effective the Enterprise Law, 
replacing the Business Law of 1994. The new law improves significantly upon the Business Law 
by (i) reducing ambiguities of procedures and shortening to 10 working days the time needed to 
register a business for investments not on the negative list, (ii) establishing a new business 
registry with the aim of providing up-to-date information on registered firms, (iii) introducing a 
negative list for enterprise registration, and (iv) removing the time-consuming interministerial 
consultative process by allowing businesses to register directly at the provincial office.  
 
55.  The Negative List for Enterprise Registration. MOIC submitted the draft negative list 
to the Prime Minister’s Office for approval. MOIC was assigned the responsibility for drafting 
and coordinating a negative list for enterprise registration. In February 2007, MOIC circulated a

59.  Import-Export  Management  System.  MOIC  has  taken  a  sequential  approach  to 
reforming  the  import-export  management  system  based  on  the  experience  of  neighboring 
countries, such as Viet Nam. The approach is to improve transparency, reduce discretion of 
trade officials, lower administrative costs, and eventually reduce the number of restricted items 
and replace some of them with more transparent forms of protection. As a first step towards this 
goal, MOIC issued a revised import and export controlled list in October 2006 (MOIC notice 
1376). The major change was reclassifying items according to the 6- to 8-digit Harmonized 
Standard (HS) code instead of the 2- to 4-digit level under the previous 2004 MOIC notification. 
This change improves transparency and reduces the discretion of trade and customs officials in 
determining whether an import item requires a nonautomatic license. Under the revised decree, 
about 80% of 2- and 4-digit items included on the import-export prohibited and controlled list 
were reclassified at the 6- to 8-digit level. The Government is committed to reclassifying the 
remaining 2-digit sectors to 8-digit level during the program period. As a second step, MOIC has 
taken actions to improve transparency in the trade regime by issuing an instruction in March 
2007 removing trade officials from the customs border posts. Their removal will help reduce the 
administrative burden for importers. The third and perhaps most significant policy reform was 
MOIC’s elimination of the requirement that producers/importers produce an import plan for the 
year approved by MOIC and local authorities. This major reform to the trade policy regime will 
reduce significantly the administrative costs to exporters and SMEs.

D.  Important Features 
 
73.  The program cluster has some distinct and innovative features. First, the Lao PDR has 
demonstrated ownership of the reform program by formulating a consistent and well-sequenced 
policy framework for private sector reforms over the medium term, as articulated in its SEDP6 
and the SME strategy. ADB’s strategy and approach has been aligned with the Government’s 
SEDP6 for 2006–2010.  
 
74.  Second, the policy framework coordinates well with ADB’s other sector reform programs, 
which are designed to support private sector development and growth. These include, for 
example, the BSRP, RFSDP, and proposed agriculture  commercialization grant program in the 
pipeline  for  2009;  and  proposed  TA  projects  for  public  expenditure  management  and 
commercialization of agriculture, as well as activities and programs under the GMS trade and 
investment framework. Although these TA projects and programs are not part of the policy

27
actions in the PSME cluster program, they support its scope and objectives and ensure regular 
policy dialogue.   
 
75.  Third,  the  program  cluster  is  a  particularly  appropriate  instrument  for  strengthening 
ADB’s partnership with the Government and enhancing relations with other constituencies in 
Lao PDR. Traditional structural adjustment lending in Lao PDR has had a poor record of 
success in recent years, damaging the reputations of the Government and its development 
partners.  The  program  cluster  provides  a  unique  opportunity  for  ADB  to  engage  with  the 
Government in a more innovative way. By basing financial assistance on completed actions 
derived from the Government’s own reform program, the program cluster offers a new way to 
strengthen the Government’s ownership of ADB strategies. By including policy triggers for 
subprogram 2, it creates a vehicle for policy dialogue and ADB support for the Government’s 
agenda. The triggers focus on outcomes and results rather than processes (i.e., how to achieve 
the outcome). The triggers deliberately avoid being overly prescriptive or predetermining at the 
outset how the Government should make the policy change to achieve the desired result. This is 
intended to reflect the reality of policy making in the Government, which requires time-intensive 
consensus building for policy reforms. In addition, the program cluster engages the new Lao 
Business Forum as a vehicle for dialogue with the private sector, other stakeholders, and 
development partners; and for monitoring the program cluster. The Government’s commitment 
to the program cluster is clear from its policy letter (Appendix 2).  
 
76.  Fourth, the PSME program cluster emphasizes institutionalizing procedures, processes 
and programs to ensure effective implementation. TA is essential to the program. It focuses on 
strengthening capabilities and institutional processes within the executing and implementing 
agencies to carry out own analytical work to broaden the Government’s reform program. TA is 
attached to each trigger and selected milestones (Appendix 3).

B.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
 
94.  The program cluster is subject to the following risks:  
 
(i)  In transitional economies, maintaining macroeconomic stability––as reflected, for 
example, in slow inflation and a stable exchange rate––is crucial for investor 
confidence  and  private  sector  growth.  Lao  PDR  is  particularly  vulnerable  to 
macroeconomic instability due to weak institutions. In addition, Lao PDR is facing 
emerging fiscal and macroeconomic challenges in the context of its resource 
export boom and associated volatile commodity prices. Recognizing these risks, 
the  Government  is  undertaking  measures  to  strengthen  public  expenditure 
management using assistance from its development partners, including ADB.  
(ii)  There  may  be  weak  coordination  among  Government  agencies  leading  to 
delayed compliance with policy measures. The adoption of the cluster mode for 
policy lending has reduced this risk in the proposed program by. By basing 
financial assistance on completed actions derived from the Government’s reform 
program, the PSME program cluster strengthens the Government’s ownership of 
the reform program. By including policy triggers for subprogram 2, the program 
offers  the  flexibility  needed  to  take  into  account  changes  in  the  external 
environment faced by Lao PDR and emerging priority policy reforms. Moreover, 
the Government has taken a clear stance on the need for policy adjustment 
regarding the SME/private sector, as articulated in its SME strategy. 
(iii)  The  capacity  of  agencies  to  implement  reforms  might  be  constrained  by 
resources and other emerging priorities. The program cluster reduces this risk by 
limiting the policy triggers to a few high-priority, high-impact policy reforms under 
the jurisdiction of MOIC and a limited number of implementing agencies (CPI and 
MOF), and by attaching TA to each policy trigger.  
(iv)  Vested interests will resist some of the reforms. Reforms to the import-export 
management system and institutionalization of economic governance reforms––
i.e., red tape review process––are likely to be long and drawn-out. However, 
several factors mitigate these risks. First, the PSME strategic approach is to 
focus efforts on supporting the Government’s initiatives. Second, reforms will

SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
1.  The sector analysis assesses the recent performance of the private sector, and provides 
the background to identification of issues, constraints, and threats and the Government’s priority 
reforms  in  support  of  private  sector  and  small  and  medium-sized  enterprises  (SME) 
development and growth.1   
 
A.   Performance of the Private Sector  
 
2.  Available data and discussions with stakeholders indicate that the performance of the 
private  sector  is  improving.  While  the  private  sector  is  relatively  small,  it  is  growing  and 
investments are occurring in sectors that Lao Peoples’ Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) has 
comparative advantage. Some preliminary evidence suggests dynamic growth among micro-, 
small, and medium-sized enterprises. 
 
3.  The economy has undergone a substantial structural transformation in the past 15 years. 
This is reflected in the expansion of industry relative to agriculture and services (Figure A5.1). 
Industry has increased from about 16% of gross domestic product (GDP) in 1990 to 23% in 
2000 and 29% in 2006, with investments in hydropower and the mining sector driving the 
industrial expansion in recent years. Agriculture’s share of GDP is declining, while the services 
sector has remained relatively stable at about 26% of GDP. Contraction of the crops subsector 
in the first half of the 1990s accounted for a large share of agriculture’s relative decline during 
this period. However, crops recovered from 25% to 30% of GDP by 2002, primarily due to large 
public investments in irrigation. This pattern of structural change is expected as an economy 
grows and develops; resources move from low-productivity activities in subsistence agriculture 
and traditional services to higher-productivity activities in industry and modern services. This 
process, and the associated rural-to-urban migration that occurs with this transformation, has 
contributed to the reduction in poverty in Lao PDR. Within industry, official statistics indicate that 
growth has been spread evenly, with the manufacturing sector enjoying robust growth rates. 
Exports  of  garments—the  major  manufacturing  export—have  grown  modestly  since  the 
completion of the phase-out of textile quotas in 2005, while many other comparable small 
exporting nations have struggled to maintain export volumes. Within services, tourism and 
related services have expanded rapidly in recent years (Figure A5.2).

4.  The private sector comprises micro-, small, and medium-scale enterprises. Data on the 
number and size distribution of establishments operating in the economy are limited. Available 
data show that the SMEs are the dominant business form in Lao PDR. Large private firms are

numbers and size are from the 2001 survey of manufacturing establishments by the Ministry of

employees, of which only 116 firms had more than 100 employees. The bulk of establishments–

distribution in the economy is typical for small, low-income developing economies. In the initial 
stages of development, the private sector is dominated by small enterprises. However, as the 
economy  expands,  competitive  firms  become  larger.  The  dominance  of  SMEs  and  the 
informality of this business form also reflect the weak regulatory and institutional environment in

B.   Reducing Transaction Costs 
 
9.  This section summarizes the main business climate impediments to private sector and 
SME development and growth. It concludes that, while much progress has been made to create 
an enabling environment for the private sector to grow, much more needs to be done to lower 
transaction  costs  by  addressing  excessive  red  tape,  improving  the  investment  climate, 
completing the unfinished trade policy agenda, and strengthening the institutional framework for 
SME policy making.  
 
10.  Although  transaction  costs  continue  to  be  high  in  Lao  PDR,  they  have  declined 
substantially. Lao PDR continues to rank low in several international surveys of competitiveness. 
High transaction costs in the regulatory environment, trade facilitation, and logistics sector 
explain part of the difference with neighboring countries. For example, Figure A5.2 shows that 
improvements in the business environment can reduce transaction costs and improve profit 
margins,  thereby  increasing  the  incentive  for  additional  investment.  Figure  A  depicts  the 
composition of free on board (FOB) price for men’s cotton long-sleeved shirts from a small 
sample  of  garment  factories  in  the  region.4 Figure  B  shows  the  impact  of  a  reduction  in 
transaction costs on profit margins for Lao PDR factories. To make it easier to view, Figure B

review the stock of regulations, estimate compliance costs to businesses and to the economy, 
and produce a reform strategy; and later (ii) institutionalize a regulatory review mechanism

C.   Maintaining Macroeconomic Stability in Support of Private Sector Growth 
 
15.  Real  Exchange  Rate.  Private  sector  and  SME  growth  in  Lao  PDR  depends  on 
macroeconomic stability. In the future, this stability will be influenced by developments in the 
resource sector. Over the next decade, the Government anticipates significant future budget 
revenues from hydropower investments and mining in the form of taxes, royalties, and dividends. 
The mining sector in particular is generating substantial revenues for the Government, and more 
are expected in the future. In 2006, the Government received more than $72 million from the 
mining sector (about 15% of national budget revenues), a figure that is projected to increase to 
$100 million in 2007 on the back of a sharp and sustained increase in commodity prices. At 
least two large mining investments are in the pipeline. For the first time in its modern history, 
Lao PDR has a tremendous opportunity to use these revenue flows to finance its development 
goals,  raise  per  capita  incomes,  and  reduce  poverty—as  another  landlocked  economy, 
Botswana, did during the diamond boom. At the same time, Lao PDR can draw important 
lessons from international experience in supporting private sector growth during a commodity 
resource boom of uncertain duration. A resource boom can affect the growth conditions of the 
nonresource sector if it leads to an excessive appreciation of the real exchange rate, which 
could slow growth of the nonresource tradable goods sector (manufacturing and agriculture). 
The manufacturing sector (especially garments) is particularly vulnerable to an excessive real 
appreciation. While unit labor costs in the Lao PDR garment sector is on par with Cambodia and

other regional neighbors,9 the sector operates with relatively lower profit margins (Table A4.2). 
Since wages are paid in kip, an excessive appreciation of the exchange rate would raise unit 
labor costs in dollar terms, squeezing profit margins. Estimates of the real kip exchange rate 
indicate  that  it  has  appreciated  faster  than  its  regional  neighbors’ currencies, although  no
